video_title: The First Laser AND Blade Cutter!  xTool M1 Laser & Blade Cutter Review
comment_text:
It's very dangerous, potentially lethal even, to laser cut materials like vinyl, chemically treated leather, ABS, PVC, and many common plastics (it will also damage the machine). But these precautions are only briefly addressed early in the video, and later on you recommend laser engraving the included leather which is definitely not veg-tanned, and is most certainly producing toxic fumes.

With a combo unit like this, using the available materials in the wrong way will definitely happen to new and uninformed users, and they will be sorry for it. This needs to be addressed early in the video!

Additionally, you may not have been paid for this review, but you were provided the machine for free and your links in the description are clearly affiliate links to the product in question. You must disclose this to your viewers.

video_title: This has some Serious POWER! Atomstack X20 Pro Laser Review
comment_text: I am sort of confused where diode lasers are going. It started out as a bare bones all safety to the wind cheap alternative to CO2. Today they are technically a far more expencive alternative to CO2 with reduced productivity and no safety features that the most basic of CO2 units have. This diode laser with a cutting base option and box to stop the house from burning down while catching the fumes is $100 / watt. Where a CO2 most basic @ double the wattage is $15 / watt and 1/3 the overall price.

video_title: It's 48x FASTER than a Diode Laser! 3PLASERS EM-Smart 20W MOPA Laser Review
comment_text: For more interesting colors on stainless you have to defocus the head about 1mm up to spread the heat out, something I've experimented with on a 70 watt Tykma large field and later heard from a former Tykma applications person. Be glad the clones cost what they do since the industrial machines are usually 15x that price. If they are running the same ripped software there should be tools to distort the marking field to match your part's contours in the absence of a rotary head.

video_title: The First Laser AND Blade Cutter!  xTool M1 Laser & Blade Cutter Review
comment_text:
Great review!! After I pre-ordered a few months back and just got mine set up for leather work. It's turning out to be invaluable, especially for prototyping. I can cut out pattern pieces of full grain leather with the knife without burning any edges, then laser engrave, all in one go. Originally, the 45-degree blades that came with the box were not able to cut through my 1.2mm veg tan, but I saw that after product launch, they released a 60-degree blade. Shipping was going to make those blades extremely expensive, so I took a risk, ran to Hobby Lobby, and bought Cricut Deep Cut blades to see if they work. They do!! Pretty sure they're the exact same blade as what xTool is selling. I would love if the Cricut knife blade would also work with the M1, but it seems more proprietary. Maybe xTool will make one. 

Take care!!

video_title: Is this feature worth $2400?  The Snapmaker 2.0 Rotary
comment_text: I bought the A350 nearly a year ago and have been pretty happy with it. Haven't bothered getting the rotary module. It doesn't feel as good as getting independent machines but then I'm in a pretty small shop so it doesn't take up a lot of space. Predominately I make boxes so the laser and cnc functions are what I use most of the time. If you were working on bigger items like furniture then I'd definitely steer clear. The unboxing and setup was first rate although I agree Luban is pretty ordinary - I wasn't even able to insert italic test for a quick laser engrave and instead had to use Inkscape.

video_title: It's 48x FASTER than a Diode Laser! 3PLASERS EM-Smart 20W MOPA Laser Review
comment_text:
Since MOPA is better for plastics, I'm curious how well a small, simple machine like this would do with PCB prototyping or small scale manufacturing. It wouldn't be too difficult to have a multi-material profile, just switch frequency and amplitude within a certain set of lines in the code. 'Etching' a PCB would be such a great alternative to the typical developing methods, as even some of the newer prototyping methods, like using a photoresist PCB blank on the LCD of an MSLA printer, still require developing in chemicals. If this could not only etch the traces, but also etch the board for proper marking, I don't see why this couldn't be a viable alternative to cheap board manufacturing. Stemming from this, I'm curious how well this kind of laser handles various solder masks, say if someone wanted to mask a whole board then etch the masking off the pads, instead of more typical processes; most PCB software already separate pads and traces, so technically you'd already have a file for just pads, with the proper settings you could potentially etch the solder mask but not the copper pad underneath. 

If it works out, something like this could be great for maker spaces, assuming someone had already gone through the calibrations for specific materials, thicknesses, etc. Even as a hobbyist or small business, a machine like this would be amazing for prototyping and small production runs.

video_title: The Nicest Laser Engraver This Year? The xTool D1 Review
comment_text:
I reached out to Xtool customer support for a D1 & accessories since I wanted to figure out if I need to pay import duty & VAT. 

They don't seem to be serious about EU law. No clarity on where they ship from. As an EU citizen, I have the right to know. 

As per EU Standard, the seller needs to tell the customer where its dispatched when placing an order, VAT, etc. If I ask about VAT, the Xtool customer support personnel is giving an inclusive response.  What I understood is partly they want to ship from the EU & partly from outside the EU. 

There is a tax obligation, depending on where they fulfill from. This needs to be clear when placing the order, if they ship from the EU, they pay VAT in one of the EU countries where you ship from. Otherwise, it's an export order, either they pay if you have IOSS registration or I need to pay on import extra cost to me. 

You are mixing up, and dogging after the initial response.  Maybe Xtool is good, but not possible to buy from with in EU.  After a week of chatting with them, now I am looking into some other brand.

video_title: It's 48x FASTER than a Diode Laser! 3PLASERS EM-Smart 20W MOPA Laser Review
comment_text: Since this laser creates an angle between the surface being cut and the beam output. Does it CUT through 3/8 thick material at a slight angle since the laser beam is NOT CUTTING from Directly above at a perfect right angle to the surface being cut.  I would like to make a whole bunch of wood puzzles and I do NOT want there to be any angles of any sort on the pieces. I want the pieces to be truely Square to the surface. So since the laser is NOT MOVED directly above I would guess that the laser is always cutting at some varying angle to the surface of material being cut which for my uses makes it a worthless device for me to have.    Thank you for your time.

video_title: My Favorite Laser Just Got Better! - xTool D1 Upgrades
comment_text: Good day Nick ! Just un boxed the honeycomb table (which I purchased through your link as with the air assist) ! Funny thing is that the side rulers are in Imperial (inches) but everything else is based on MM . Also my air assist only came with one nozzle ...But mine did come with a switch . To solve the issue with all the extra hose as you pointed out I was able to add a small shelf above the D1 and added a loose fitting wire tie around it and the wire harness so they travel together , no issues so far. Time for a clink and install table . as always thanks for all your videos and help ! Keep up the informative and entertaining stuff ! Cheers !!       John in Florida    A.K.A.  Fla Dude  🙂✌

video_title: It's 48x FASTER than a Diode Laser! 3PLASERS EM-Smart 20W MOPA Laser Review
